editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

(His Excellency) General of all the Forces rai≈øed for the regaining of Englands Liberty; the Honorable the Commanders in chief, and others the Commanders and Soldiers of the pious and victorious Army; Now appearing (as Englands Champions) for the maintainance of Gods honor, and this their native Countries ju≈øt Liberty, Peace, and Tranquillity.

The humble Petition of all the in≈ølaved Chri≈øtians in the ≈øeveral Slaughter-hou≈øe so, this Kingdom (called Gaols and Pri≈øons) being your Brethren & Fellow-Common of England (conceived to be about 10000 in number) impri≈øoned for Debt, and by Arb ‚Ä¢ trary Power, and other illegal re≈øtraints, contrary to the I aw of God, and all other Nations both Chri≈øtian and Pagan, and flatly again≈øt the Contents of the great Charter of Englands Liberty, formerly purcha≈øed, and now againe regained by the blood of many thou≈øands of the Commons of England. In all humility complaining, Sheweth,
div.p:
THat by the ancient and fundamental common Laws of England Mirror of Ju≈øtice cha. 5. Int. 1. num. 57 declared and a≈ø≈øerted by the great Charter of our Liberties 9 of Hen. 3. cha, 8. Magna Charta, no mans per≈øon was to be Impri≈øoned for Debt, nor his Sureties to be troubled, if the principal Debtor were able to pay: But their E≈øtates only made liable (in the two third parts thereof) to ≈øatisfie the Debt: Which Statute being the inexpugnable fortre≈øs of Englands Freedom, Hath not only been 32. times confirmed by ≈øeveral Acts of Parliament, in former Kings reigns,
Cooks In≈øtit. 4 part P. 35. Anno 3. Caro. Anno 17. Caroli but al≈øo hath been ≈øince ratified by our Soveraign Lord King Charls, both by the Petition of Right, 3o Car. and by Act pa≈ø≈øed by his Maje≈øties royal a≈ø≈øent this pre≈øent Parliament (Anno 17. Caroli.) Again≈øt which Charter, All Statutes and Judgments formerly made or given, or hereafter to be made or given, are 28 of Ed. 1. c. 1. 42 Ed. 3. cha, 1. by ≈øeveral Acts declared to be null and voyd:
Fleta p. 1. c. 26. Bracton P. 3. fol. 105. & 137. Britton c. 5. ≈øo. 14. Mirror c. 2. ≈øect. 9. al≈øo c. 5 ≈øect. 1. 8 Ed. 2. Fits Coron. 432. 7 Edw. 3. BR. rot. 44.24 He. 8 Di ‚Ä¢ r 249. P ‚Ä¢ e Com. 360. Cook l. 3. fo 44 lib. 8. fo. 100. vox plebis P. 55, 56, 57. Oppre≈ø≈øed mans Oppre≈ø≈øion P. 2, 3, 4. And that neither tho≈øe that are impri≈øoned for Debt at the Kings ≈øuit only, nor any others committed for Trea≈øon, Felony, Murther, or Tre≈øpa≈øs, before conviction or attainder, ought to be put into Irons, or otherwi≈øe to be puni≈øhed, but only to be ≈øafely kept; Pri≈øons being only for cu≈øtody and not for puni≈øhment to the Pri≈øoners. Mirror c 4. ≈øect. 9. And whereas by the ≈øaid common Laws of England, Gaolers that detain their Pri≈øoners in Pri≈øon, by colour of right for their fees until they dye, or cau≈øe their Pri≈øoners to peri≈øh by famine, beating or wounding, by hard u≈øage, ≈øtrickt or clo≈øe Dure≈øs, or by putting them into Irons or Dungeons which procure their death, are guilty of Homicide or Man-≈ølaughter.

That by the ≈øaid Laws, Gaolers or Guardians of Pri≈øons are prohibited to ≈øpoil their Pri≈øoners of their goods, or to take any thing from them, for, by, or under any pretence of Fees, either at their coming into the Pri≈øon or going out Mirror c. 5. ≈øect. 1. Mirror 52, 53.: And whereas likewi≈øe, all manner of Extortions, Oppre≈ø≈øions and illegal vexation of Sherifes, Gaolers, and Pri≈øon-Keepers, exerci≈øed and practiced upon their Pri≈øoners, is ≈øtrictly prohibited and defended by divers good and whol≈øome Laws and Statutes of this Realm 4 Ed. 3. c. 10 23 He. 6. c. 10. 3 Ed. 1. c. 26. 25 Ed. 3 c. 17. Liberty again≈øt ≈ølavery ≈øo. 4, 5, 7.: And Gaolers and Guardians of Pri≈øons (and Sherifes) are to take nothing for the execution of their offices, but only of the King, except 4 pence to be required and taken of the Pri≈øoner at the time of his di≈øcharge and not before, conferred on them by the Statute of the 23. of Henry 6. chap. 10.

That contrary to the≈øe good Statutes (and the great Charter of Englands Liberty) the per≈øons of the free-commons of England are ≈øtill mo≈øt unju≈øtly and cruelly (for an unlimited time) in≈ølaved in the ≈øeveral Gaols and Pri≈øons, and thereby inhumanly robbed of their ju≈øt and precious Liberties, E≈øtates and Callings, whereby they, their wives and children are expo≈øed to the cruel wills of their Oppre≈ø≈øors, and ≈øo become the very ≈øpectacle of mi≈øery; not pityed by any, nor hitherto by the State regarded nor relieved: Notwith≈øtanding their many ≈øeveral Petitions (for the≈øe 6 years pa≈øt) pre≈øented to them for Relea≈øe from this Aegyptian bondage. That in pur≈øuance of their uncontroubled inhumane cruelties, Gaolers and Pri≈øon-keepers have and dayly do inforce from Pri≈øoners their goods and moneys, illegal fees and exce≈ø≈øive Chamber-rent; viz. Fees of a Mark, five Mark, five pound, and ten pound, and for Chamber-Rent from each Pri≈øoner no le≈øs then 5 s. 8 s. 10 s. yea from ≈øome 20 s. a week, and in the Common Wards, where nothing of Right ought to be by them required or taken; they exact from each poor pri≈øoner (although two lodged in one bed) no le≈øs then 14. pence a week, be≈øides divers others unexpre≈ø≈øible exactions. That many hundreds of pri≈øoners have been (as ≈øome ≈øtill are) by Gaolers and Pri≈øon-keepers and their helli≈øh Sub≈øtitutes clo≈øe impri≈øoned in Chambers and Dungeons, for divers days, moneths and years, a≈ø≈øaulted, beaten, wounded, robbed, and violently at midnight dragg'd out of their own beds and lodged on the cold bare ground; Tormented and decripped by Iron Fetters, ≈øtarved and violently murthered; yea, ≈øome kept in Irons (hands and feet) till their Excrements coming from their body rotted their fundaments; Others being by their creditors di≈øcharged, are notwith≈øtanding by Gaolers detained in Pri≈øon meerly for their own unju≈øt exacting
fees, where many have thus mi≈øerably peri≈øhed: And al≈øo u≈øually comi ‚Ä¢
ing Felons & Murtherers with Debtors, contrary to the Statute of ≈øafety. Thus Pri≈øons are none other then places of Torment, ruin, and de≈øtruction to the Commons of England; and Gaolers and Pri≈øon-Keepers none other then tormenters and lawle≈øs executioners of their own eruel wils, who, although complained of, yet the Pri≈øoners ju≈øt complaints are not heard, but they ≈øtil ≈øuffered to per≈øi≈øt in the≈øe their cruel illegal cour≈øes, and like vipers ≈øucking the vital blood of the poor Pri≈øoners, and defrauding them of their Legacies and Collection moneys gathered in every County of this Realm, and Courts of Ju≈øtice for their relief, they murther the poor innocent, to whom they deny the priviledg which is by them dayly afforded unto Felons.

The premi≈øes ju≈øtly weighed, and for that Impri≈øonment of the body for 10, 20, 30, or 40. years, di≈øcounts not one penny of Debt to the Creditor, but only for a time brings the Gri≈øt of wicked gain to the Lawyers and Attornies covetous mills of ungodly contention, with inevitable ruin to the Debtor, his wife, children and family; Lawyers, Attornies and Gaolers being none other then poor, di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, in≈ølaved Englands Canker-worms, and devouring Caterpillers of mens E≈øtates, Liberties and lives. The Law of England being a Law of mercy and pre≈øervation to the people, and not a law of Tyranny, Oppre≈ø≈øion and De≈øtruction, as hitherto it hath been and ≈øtill is „Äà‚óä„Äâ ; By which law the the two third parts only of the Debtors E≈øtate is made liable to the ≈øatisfaction of his ju≈øt Debts, the re≈øt being re≈øerved to the Debtor for his future ≈øub≈øi≈øtance and education of his children, and the per≈øons acquitted from future trouble for the ≈øame.

Your poor di≈øtre≈ø≈øed and unju≈øtly in≈ølaved Petitioners do therefore humble be≈øeech you (in the bowels of compa≈ø≈øion) to commi≈øerate this their grievous unlimited oppre≈ø≈øive condition of being; and according to the rules of ju≈øtice and charity (and the pious ≈øen≈øibility of your unju≈øtly in≈ølaved Brethrens mi≈øery) to be plea≈øed, among≈øt other your weighty and humble Addre≈ø≈øes to the high and honorable Court of Parliament, to pre≈øent the≈øe our grievances & ju≈øt reque≈øts with de≈øire, That according to the fundamental Laws of the land, the per≈øons of all the Commons of England may be re≈øtored to their ancient, legal and ju≈øt Liberties (as at the fir≈øt); and that the current of Ju≈øtice may be freely opened to all; That ≈øo the poor Commons of England may not ≈øtill be inforced (by mercenary Lawyers and contentious Attornies) to buy Ju≈øtice for the corrupt price of iniquity; nor at ≈øuch high rates as hitherto they have been inforced to do, to the utter
ruin of their E≈øtates, Hou≈øes, and Families: Your Petitioners not being able to acquit them≈øelves from this inhumane ≈ølavery, by the abominable, unlimited, chargeable cour≈øe of the law, practiced by all the mercenary in≈øtruments of contention, in Petty-fogging latine and Pedlers French, by the≈øe ≈øupporters of contention; And al≈øo that Gaolers and Pri≈øon-Keepers may be regulated in their illegal, unlimited tyrannical power, potency, cruelty, and exactions, that ≈øo we and the po≈øterity of this whole Nation being freed from this Aegyptian bondage, may have ju≈øt cau≈øe to eternize the memory of your Excellency and the re≈øt of the honorable Commanders and pious Souldiery (truths faithful Champions) as of the true and faithful re≈øtorers of the ancient and ju≈øt birth-right, and liberty of the in≈ølaved Commons of England: And your Petitioners, their wives, and children, and families (as bound] ≈øhal ever pray for a ble≈ø≈øing on your faithful endeavors, and for the ≈øpeedy ≈øucce≈ø≈øes of this bleeding Kingdoms cau≈øe by you taken in hand, to Gods glory and Englands Peace and Tranquillity.

postscript.p: And I rebuked the Nobles and Rulers, ≈øaying, You exact u≈øury every one of his brother, and I ≈øet a great A≈ø≈øembly again≈øt them; For I was very angry when I heard the cry [of the oppre≈ø≈øed] and I ≈øaid, Our fle≈øh is as the fle≈øh of our Brethren, our children as their children: and ‚Ä¢ o we bring into bondage our ≈øons and our daughters: And I ≈øaid, It is not good, that which ye do; ought ye not to walk in the fear of our God, Nehemiah 5.5, 6, 7, 9? div.head: To the right Honorable the LORDS and COMMONS in PARLIAMENT a≈ø≈øembled at We≈øtmin≈øter.

The humble Petition of divers wel affected Commons of England, in the behalf of them≈øelves and others their in≈ølaved Fellow Commons, impri≈øoned for Debt and other illegat re≈øtraints, within the ≈øeveral Pri≈øons in this Kingdom, conceived to be about 10000. in number (at the lea≈øt) Complaining, Sheweth,
div.p: THat the≈øe their fellow Commons In≈ølaved, having formerly, by ≈øeveral Petitions addre≈ø≈øed them≈øelves to this Honorable a≈ø≈øembly, for their undeniable Birth-right (which is their Liberty) and aquittance from this unlimitted Impri≈øonment fa≈øtened on them, and us; And the po≈øterity of this whole Nation, By the covetous In≈øtruments of contention, through their unexpre≈ø≈øible abu≈øe of Magna Charta, which is the only Sure Contract and perpetual Law, between the King and his Subjects, In all which They nor We, have hitherto reaped any Redre≈øs According to our ju≈øt Expectation: That in the 3. year of the King, The body of this Common-wealth being Sen≈øible of many Sufferings. Occa≈øioned by the breach of Magna Charta, The Lords and Commons then a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, Petitioned his Maje≈øty for Confirmation thereof (Which Implies their con≈øents to it) To which his Maje≈øty then a≈ø≈øented and ≈øince Confirmed (Which Implies an Act, and a legal confirmation) whereby we truly apprehend. That all Latter Statutes made in Contradiction thereof. Tending to the betraying of the Subjects Liberty (By in≈ølaving their Per≈øons) are ab≈øolutely become Null, and cannot now ≈øtand in force, as by the 42. of Ed. 3. c. 1. appeareth; For the le≈ø≈øer mu≈øt needs give Place to this Greater. It having al≈øo bin maintained in this Honorable a≈ø≈øembly, That the Commons mu≈øt be ea≈øed in their Per≈øons from this Slavery of Impri≈øonment being a free born people and no Slaves nor villians, Impri≈øonment being flatly again≈øt Magna Charta, which is the only foundamental Mother Law of this Kingdom, 26 Edw. 3. c. 4. Purcha≈øed (and now again Regained) by the Blood of many thou≈øands of our Ance≈øtors, Freinds and Allies.

The premi≈øes Con≈øidered, and for that it is wel known, that Impri≈øonment of the body for 10.20.30. or 40. years together, di≈øcounts not one penny Debt to the Creditor, but only (For a time) brings Gri≈øt to the Lawyers and Atturnies mills of Wicked contention,
Gain to the Cruel-Gaoler and his Sub≈øtitutes, with Inevitable Ruin to the Poor Debtor (his Wife, children, and Family) who by this Cruelty is Debarred of his precious Liberty; livelyhood, and calling: your petitioners therefore humbly pray, that according to the pious Rule of Ju≈øtice and Charity, and the fundamental Law of this Land, All the per≈øons of the Commons of England may be Re≈øtored to their ancient Legal and ju≈øt Liberty (as at the fir≈øt) and the Current of Ju≈øtice freely opened to all, which your Petitioners humbly Conceive cannot be truly Effected: ≈øo long as Lawyers and Atturnies (The Covetous Mercinary In≈øtruments of contention) be permitted to ≈øit in the Hou≈øe, who are Conceived to be the only Ob≈øtructors of Ju≈øtice in this Kingdom. This being done, your Petitioners as al≈øo their unju≈øtly In≈ølaved Brethren wil then (as is hoped) be Inabled to partake of Ju≈øtice Freely: and not ≈øtil be Inforced (by Lawyers and Atturnies) to buy it for the Corrupt price of Iniquity, nor at ≈øuch high Rates as hitherto they have done, to the utter Ruin of their E≈øtates, Hou≈øes and Families: And that according to Magna Charta, the Debtors E≈øtates, (if any Remaining) may be made Lyable (In the two third parts thereof) to the ≈øatisfaction of their Ju≈øt Debts, By which great Charter, a Charitable Con≈øideration is had to the future Sub≈øi≈øtence of the Debtors, their wives and children, and al≈øo that Pri≈øons may be Regulated, and Pri≈øon keepers, abridged of their Illegal, unlimitted, Tyrannical Power, Potency, and Exactions. That ≈øo we and all our Po≈øterities being ≈øteed from this Aegyptian bondage, may have Ju≈øt cau≈øe to Eternize the memory of his Maje≈øty, and of this Honorable a≈ø≈øembly, as of the Re≈øtorers of their Ancient and Ju≈øt Birth-right and Liberty.

div.head: To the Honorable the Hou≈øe of Commons in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled.
The humble Petition of divers wel. affected Commons of England, in the behalf of their poor in≈ølaved Brethren, langui≈øhing in ≈øeveral Pri≈øon, with ‚Ä¢ n this Kingdom. Mo≈øt humbly ≈øheweth,
div.p:
THat this Honorable A≈ø≈øembly was plea≈øed ≈øome 5. years ≈øince to heare the Petition of the poor pri≈øoners for Debt, and to refer the fame to a Committee (whereof Henry Martine E≈øquire was then Chairman) for the drawing up of an Ordinance for their remedy and redre≈øs, which was done accordingly, But yet hitherto unhappily ob≈øtructed, whereby many poor Pri≈øoners (their wives and children) for want of timely redre≈øs, have ≈øince peri≈øhed, and many others are con≈øumed and utterly di≈øabled to ≈øub≈øi≈øt. Now for that the ≈øaid Ordinance was long ≈øince re≈øolved on, and by M. Martine brought into this Honorable Hou≈øe to be read; Yet there hitherto ob≈øtructed, ≈øo as the hearts of the oppre≈ø≈øed (through this long delay) ready faynt
within them, their mi≈øeries being thereby augmented, and for that al≈øo, a great number, who have with al fidelity ≈øerved the Parliament, and have not received their pay (Due) are at this pre≈øent Impri≈øoned for their debts, which they can no ways ≈øatisfy until they have received their arrears for the ≈øaid ≈øervic ‚Ä¢ , by which means many of them have peri≈øhed, and the re≈øt likely to peri≈øh mi≈øerably, and their families to be utterly ruined.

Your poor Petitioners therefore in the bleeding ≈øence of their (unju≈øtly in≈ølaved) brethrens extream ≈øufferings, do humbly pray; That ye the cho≈øen, convened for their deliverance from oppre≈ø≈øion and inju≈øtice, and for the pre≈øervation of their ju≈øt Rights and Liberties, wil now (after ≈øo long time of their expectancy (in durance and mi≈øery) be plea≈øed forthwith to comi≈øerate their deplorable e≈øtates, and according to your duty, the fundamental Law of the Land, and Petition of Right; ≈øeriou≈øly to con≈øider the premi≈øes, and ≈øpeedily according to ju≈øtice, to a≈ø≈øign unto every of them their ju≈øt liberty & freedom, from this unju≈øt bondage and ≈ølavery; They having long cryed and none have regarded this their unju≈øtly impo≈øed mi≈øerable Thraldom; in which not only the pre≈øent Petitioners, but the po≈øterity of all the freeborn Commons of England are meerly concerned; this being by you accompli≈øhed, then not only your Petitioners, but future generations ≈øhal be ever bound to call you the ble≈ø≈øed in≈øtruments of ju≈øtice, for the Regaining of their ancient and ju≈øt Rights and Liberties.

Ye ≈øhal do no unrighteou≈øne≈øs in judgment, Levi. 19.15. Thou ≈øhalt not oppre≈øs nor vex the ≈øtranger, the widdow, the fatherle≈øs child, nor the poor. For if thou afflict them and they cry unto me. I wil ≈øurely heare their cry: And my wrath ≈øhal wax hot, and I wil kill you with the ≈øword: and your wives ≈øhal be widdows, and your children fatherle≈øs, Exod. 22.21, 22, 23, 24. Therefore execute true judgment, ≈øhew mercy and compa≈ø≈øion every man to his Brother, and oppre≈øs not the widdow, the ≈øtranger, nor the poor, and let none of you imagine evil again≈øt his brother in your heart, and execute the judgment of truth and Peace in your Gates, and love no fal≈øe oaths Zach. 7.9, 10. Zach. 8.16, 17. Nor ≈øel ju≈øtice for the price of iniquity as hitherto you have done. vivat rex.

argument.p: Many more Petitions of the like nature being from time to time pre≈øented, have bin ob≈øtructed, and the parties greived, not heard nor releived, but their mi≈øerable Bondage rather augmented, and they thereby di≈øcouraged from renewing their complaints again≈øt the≈øe their Aegyptian task-ma≈øters, viz. Lawyers, Attornies, Gaolers, and cruel creditors, Di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, and mi≈øerably in≈ølaved, Englands Canker-wormes, and devouring Caterpillers of mens E≈øtates, Liberties, and lives, and formenters of all Contention, Tyranny, and Oppre≈ø≈øion.
